entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes all the cage doors to rust with age and weaken, allowing the owls to break free. There is a {@chance 50} chance that the giant owl also ages into an undead version of itself that attacks until destroyed. The {@creature Skeletal Giant Owl|IMR|skeletal, rotted creature} uses the {@creature giant owl} stat block with the following changes:

items: It has the undead type instead of the beast type.
It has vulnerability to bludgeoning damage.
It is immune to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition, and is immune to {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: 13. Bear Laboratory
entries: Whenever anyone enters this area, a low growling rises from the animals kept here. A number of large, sturdy cages house one pair each of {@creature Black Bear||black bears}, {@creature Brown Bear||brown bears}, and {@creature Polar Bear||polar bears}. In addition, shelves and cupboards throughout the room hold dried fish, dried berries, and grubs as food for the bears, along with tools and supplies.
Any character who feeds the bears or succeeds on a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check can successfully quiet them.

entries.name: Barbatos
entries: The ranger {@creature Barbatos|IMR} is either here or in area 12 (a {@chance 50} chance for either), accompanied by his {@creature hell hound} companion, Sadie III. See {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for his stat block, and {@area area 12|102|x} for more information.

entries.name: Bears
entries: If the bears are freed, they scatter throughout the temple, attacking anyone they see before eventually making their way to {@area area 1|0c6|x} and up the stairs. If {@creature Barbatos|IMR} is still in the room when the bears escape, they attack him first.

A character who succeeds on a DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check can convince at least one of the bears (of your choice) to remain with the party for the duration of the adventure. Feeding the bears first provides advantage on this check.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes all the cage doors to rust with age and weaken, allowing the bears to break free. There is a {@chance 50} chance that both polar bears also age into undead versions of themselves that attack anyone in the room until destroyed. Each {@creature Skeletal Polar Bear|IMR|skeletal, rotted bear} uses the {@creature polar bear} stat block with the following changes:

items: It has the undead type instead of the beast type.
It has vulnerability to bludgeoning damage.
It is immune to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition, and is immune to {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: 14. Main Laboratory (North)
entries: Depending on how they move through this area, the characters might see into {@area area 16|119|x} at the same time. See that area for additional details.

A massive L-shaped laboratory space is filled with creatures strapped down to tables or chained to the floor, all attended to by lizardfolk workers. In this north wing of the lab, two tables hold terrified-looking fish-folk of some kind, connected by silver wires to other tables holding stoic-looking lizardfolk. More silver wires connect the tables to a complex control panel standing between them.

The experiment underway in this area involves transferring and enhancing the amphibiousness of locathah prisoners to {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s loyal lizardfolk guards. (The artificer's aim is to establish a permanent population of lizardfolk in the underground lake to uncover more of the gems there.)

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature Lizardfolk Shaman||lizardfolk shamans} work here as lab managers, overseeing two {@creature Lizardfolk Render|GoS|lizardfolk renders} connected to a pair of {@creature locathah|GoS}. If attacked, the shamans release the renders to take on the characters, then one shaman flees to alert the rest of the laboratory section of the temple (areas 1 through 23).

If the locathah are freed, they attempt to flee for {@area area 2|0cd|x}, hoping to escape the temple via the river. However, a successful DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check can convince them to remain with the characters for the duration of the adventure, as long as they can access fresh water every 4 hours.

entries.name: Control Panel
entries: The control panel is covered with dials, switches, and buttons—including a cloudy orange button recognizable as one of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Removing this component deactivates the controls and releases the restraints on the tables, freeing all the creatures in this area.

Anyone attempting to disrupt the controls or the wires must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) force damage. The controls and the wires are self-repairing, and cannot be severed or destroyed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Any search of the room finds two vials of {@item Thessaltoxin|IMR|thessaltoxin poison} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}), whose polymorph capabilities are being used to facilitate the experiments here.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the lizardfolk renders on the tables to devolve back into standard {@creature lizardfolk}.

entries.name: 15. Thessalar's Laboratory
entries: Adjoining the main laboratory, {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s private lab is the site of the artificer's most challenging experiments.

Amazing instruments of complex design fill this laboratory, all seemingly engaged in active experimentation. Facing the doorway is a wooden desk, its legs resembling four small dryads whose outstretched hands are clasped together to support a desktop littered with thick tomes, alchemical vessels, and a complex control panel.
An ancient male human sits behind the desk, with a homunculus perched on his shoulder.

"More of {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s mercenaries, I presume?" the figure asks wearily. "I still haven't disposed of the last poor souls the so-called master of the tomb sent here." The homunculus then pulls the alchemist's face into an expression of wry contempt.

entries.name: Thessalar
entries: The imperturbable artificer {@creature Thessalar|IMR} readily converses with the characters, albeit with a domineering attitude. His starting assumption is that they've been sent by {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, and he wants to learn as much about his rival's machinations as he can. See {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for his stat block.

entries.name: Grand Experiments
entries: If the characters poke around the room while speaking with {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, they can take in some of the experiments on display. These include the following, along with whatever other odd and wondrous examples you might think of:

items: Orreries display unknown planets and various models of the planes.
Glass piping connects tanks holding strange liquids and materials, all in an ongoing state of transmutation.
A miniaturized human lies in apparent stasis in a windowed glass case.
A vermiform pseudodragon twists and crawls about inside a large crystal tank.
A colony of ants is constructing an elaborate city system in a huge glass tank—complete with an ant lion larva to which tiny insect victims are being sacrificed.

entries.name: Thessalar's Bargain
entries: {@creature Thessalar|IMR} knows about the {@i Infernal Machine} components in the temple, and appears to entertain the notion of bargaining with the characters for them. In truth, he will never part with them as long as they fuel his experiments, and he looks to subvert any deal by eventually feeding the characters to the thessalkraken in the subterranean lake.
In exchange for the components in his possession, {@creature Thessalar|IMR} proposes any of the following options:

items: The characters can travel to the Tomb of Horrors (see {@adventure chapter 3|IMR|3}) to recover {@creature Seodra|IMR}'s plans for crafting the jeweled skull of a demilich, as well as the remaining jeweled teeth (both in {@area area 18a|0aa|x} of the tomb). This will allow the captured gemsmith to complete the skull for {@creature Thessalar|IMR} instead.

The characters can instead travel to the tomb to either facilitate a prisoner exchange (offering {@creature Seodra|IMR} for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s missing sculptors), or to disrupt its construction by stealing {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s plans for the tomb.

entries: The distance between the Temple of Moloch and the Tomb of Horrors is left to your determination, as are the details of the overland journey. If you don't want to play out that journey, the characters' mechanical guide can use its teleportation ability to take them to the tomb.

If the characters have already caused trouble in the temple, or if {@creature Thessalar|IMR} suspects they will, he might just task them with the "easy challenge" of collecting gemstones from the temple's subterranean lake as replacements for the missing components—without mentioning the thessalkraken that dwells there.

entries.name: Homunculus
entries: Resembling an impish version of Moloch (complete with small ruby eyes worth 100 gp each), {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s homunculus assists with the artificer's experiments, and acts as a conduit for the complicated weave of magic in the Temple of Moloch. If the homunculus is destroyed, the eidolon in the main temple ({@area area 25|13a|x}) must immediately use its Incorporeal Movement trait to enter the nearest available sacred statue, where it remains trapped. If no sacred statues are available, the eidolon is destroyed.
{@creature Thessalar's homunculus|IMR} uses the normal stat block with the following change:

items: The homunculus has the following additional attack option: {@b {@i Acidic Spittle}.} {@i Ranged Weapon Attack}: +4 to hit, range 30 ft., one target. {@i Hit}: 5 ({@dice 1d6 + 2}) acid damage.

entries.name: Control Panel
entries: The control panel on the desk is covered with dials, switches, and buttons—including three emerald-green buttons recognizable as missing components from the {@i Infernal Machine}. Removing these missing components deactivates the controls and releases the {@creature pseudodragon} and the ant swarm (use the {@creature swarm of insects} stat block), which attack the nearest creatures until destroyed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The table is, in fact, crafted from four dryads, all subject to a diminution effect and subsequently {@condition petrified}. If the characters have the ability to undo this state for all of them, the dryads are grateful to them. They promise a favor of your determination, then leave the temple for the nearby woods where they once dwelled.

If this area is searched, a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check uncovers research notes regarding {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s experiments, including his creation of the various thessalbeasts and the owlbear. The miniaturized human in stasis is described as a prototype phylactery, and is part of the artificer's research into lichdom. Other notes mention Nolzur's apprenticeship and the experiments with his blood (see {@area area 7|076|x} of {@adventure chapter 3|IMR|3}) and how the silver wires can be used to attach the organs of creatures to other hosts (including {@creature Barbatos|IMR} in areas 12 or 13, and the ettin in {@area area 35|15f|x}).

In addition, this area contains {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}, an {@item herbalism kit|PHB}, two vials each of {@item Thessaltoxin|IMR|thessaltoxin poison} and {@item thessaltoxin antidote|IMR} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}), a box of ten {@item Paper Bird|WDH|paper birds} ({@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}), and a strongbox containing three exceptional rubies worth 500 gp each.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area has no effect on {@creature Thessalar|IMR} or his homunculus, but one of the experiments in the lab randomly advances as you determine. For example, using 1 charge might cause the pseudodragon to age into an undead pseudo-dracolich form, the miniature human to revert into a miniature baby that wakes from stasis and starts crying, and so forth.

entries.name: 16. Main Laboratory (South)
entries: Depending on how they move through this area, the characters might see into {@area area 14|10a|x} at the same time. See that area for additional details.

A massive L-shaped laboratory space is filled with creatures strapped down to tables or chained to the floor, all attended to by lizardfolk workers. In this west wing of the lab, two owlbears are chained to the floor, connected by silver wires to a third creature that appears to be a two-headed owlbear. More silver wire connects their restraints to a complex control panel standing between them.
The experiment underway in this area involves creating a two-headed owlbear by infusing an owlbear—a classic creation of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s—with ettin's blood.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature Lizardfolk Shaman||lizardfolk shamans} work here as lab managers, overseeing the process by which two {@creature Owlbear||owlbears} are fueling the creation of a new creature—a {@creature two-headed owlbear|IMR} nicknamed Bear-Bear (see {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for its stat block). If the lizardfolk shamans are attacked, they release the owlbears and the two-headed owlbear to take on the characters, then flee to alert the rest of the laboratory section of the temple (areas 1 through 23).

If the owlbears or their two-headed kin are freed, the cruel experiments performed on them have pushed them all to the breaking point. They ignore each other but attack any other creatures they can see.

entries.name: Control Panel
entries: The control panel is covered with dials, switches, and buttons—including a light-purple button recognizable as one of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Removing this component deactivates the controls and releases the restraints on the tables, freeing all the creatures in this area.

Anyone attempting to disrupt the controls or the wires must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) force damage. The controls and the wires are self-repairing, and cannot be severed or destroyed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Any search of the room recovers two vials of {@item Thessaltoxin|IMR|thessaltoxin poison} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}) and a vial labeled "Distilled Ettin Blood" (worth 25 gp to an alchemist), all used to facilitate the experiments here.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the owlbears' chains to rust with age and weaken, even as the owlbears age into undead versions, break free, and attack until destroyed. Each of the skeletal, rotted creatures uses the {@creature skeletal owlbear|IMR} or {@creature skeletal two-headed owlbear|IMR} stat block which includes the following changes:

items: It has the undead type instead of the monstrosity type.
It has vulnerability to bludgeoning damage.
It is immune to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition, and is immune to {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: 17. Midden
entries: As the characters approach this area, a foul stench begins to rise. When the door is opened, read:
The stench from the chamber beyond the door delivers a punch like an angered demigod. The floor slopes toward an open pit at its center, and is covered in a layer of waste, blood, and viscera.

The temple residents bring their refuse to this filthy chamber, including organic waste from the various laboratories. The foul debris here is ankle deep at the edges of the chamber, rising to knee deep closer to the center where the floor slopes toward the pit (area 18).

Upon entering this area, a character must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour. Each character who moves across the floor must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity check or fall {@condition prone} at the end of their move. If the check fails by 5 or more, the character slides 5 feet closer to the pit.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes a {@creature lizardfolk} to appear here with a bucket of waste to dispose of. The lizardfolk ignores the characters, expecting that anyone hanging out in the midden must have some good reason to do so.

entries.name: 18. Disposal Pit
entries: This open pit collects the waste thrown into the midden (area 17), where it feeds the {@creature otyugh} that dwells in the pit. If any creature moves within 5 feet of the pit, the otyugh clambers out and attacks.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge within 5 feet of the pit evolves the otyugh into a {@creature neo-otyugh|IMR}, which leaves the pit and attacks any creatures it can see. If the characters flee, the neo-otyugh begins to roam the temple, attacking all creatures as it looks to establish itself as the new ruler of the site.

entries.name: 19. Sitting Room
entries: Serving as {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s private study, this area is richly furnished with ornate tables, chairs, and cabinets all carved from expensive stone. A fireplace along the west wall is carved to resemble a smaller version of the famed statue of Moloch in the main temple ({@area area 25|13a|x}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: With successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks made to search this area, the characters can uncover several items of interest:

items: A vial of {@item Thessaltoxin|IMR|thessaltoxin poison} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8})
A tiny {@creature mimic} in the shape of a jewelry box; the mimic deals half damage with its pseudopod and bite attacks, and has only 1 hit point
Three rubies (worth 200 gp each)
A piece of river crystal (400 gp)

entries: In addition, designs can be found for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s homunculus, indicating how it was crafted from a sliver of the statue of Moloch, and hinting that its destruction will disrupt the eidolon in {@area area 25|13a|x}.

entries.name: 20. Thessalar's Bedroom
entries: {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s private sleeping quarters are richly furnished with an ornate bed, chests filled with clothes, and other personal effects. A fireplace along the east wall resembles a smaller version of the famed statue of Moloch in the main temple ({@area area 25|13a|x}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check made to search this area uncovers a key to the treasure vault in {@area area 38|16b|x} (set with a small ruby worth 20 gp). In addition, journal entries hint at {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s immunity to poison and his vulnerability to magic potions and salves that restore hit points.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes {@creature Thessalar|IMR} to return here from his private lab ({@area area 15|110|x}) and prepare to rest. His homunculus remains in the lab to clean up experiments in progress, providing the characters with a window of opportunity to deal with it alone if they so choose.

entries.name: 21. Elite Guard Barracks
entries: This damp chamber is filled with dry straw sleeping palettes, and houses the guards responsible for the protection of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s apartments and laboratories.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Three {@creature Lizardfolk Render|GoS|lizardfolk renders} are stationed here. They attack any intruders to subdue them, then drag them before {@creature Thessalar|IMR} in {@area area 15|110|x}.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area reverses time and causes the lizardfolk to head into the temple complex to search for {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, believing the thieves have just arrived. You determine where the guards might be encountered as a result.

This laboratory space is filled with worktables holding tubing, glassware, and all manner of alchemical experiments. All the various experiments are connected by silver wires to a complex control panel.

entries.name: Control Panel
entries: The control panel is covered with dials, switches, and buttons—including a hazy yellow button recognizable as one of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Removing this component deactivates the controls and shuts down all the experiments underway here.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Any search of this area recovers a set of {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}, a set of {@item glassblower's tools|PHB}, and a set of {@item tinker's tools|PHB}. In addition, a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check identifies two vials of {@item Thessaltoxin|IMR|thessaltoxin poison}, one vial of {@item blood of the lycanthrope antidote|IMR}, one vial of {@item mummy rot antidote|IMR}, and one vial of {@item thessaltoxin antidote|IMR}. See {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8} for all these items.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area advances the experiments underway here, producing three identical vials of liquid. One is water, one is a {@item potion of poison}, and one is a potion chosen by you.

entries.name: 23. Body Tanks
entries: If the characters have met {@creature Thessalar|IMR} already, they recognize the bodies in the tank as the artificer. Adjust the following read-aloud text accordingly:

This chamber holds a half-dozen floor-to-ceiling glass tanks, four of which are filled with a light-blue fluid in which the body of an elderly male human is suspended. Three of the bodies appear lifeless and inert. The fourth looks toward you and mouths silent words.

{@creature Thessalar|IMR} maintains several clones in tanks of preserving chemicals here, prepared by the spell of the same name and awaiting his use. Three clones are inert. The fourth has managed to gain a degree of sentience from its proximity to the magic of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}, and mouths its demand to be set free. If freed, it claims to be the true {@creature Thessalar|IMR} and that the artificer in {@area area 15|110|x} is an impostor.
Any freed clone uses the same stat block as {@creature Thessalar|IMR} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}) but lacks his special equipment and his homunculus.

entries.name: Concealed Door
entries: Located at the back of an empty tank, this locked door leads to {@area area 9|0eb|x}. It can be detected with a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Without the key carried by {@creature Andras|IMR}, its lock can be picked with a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or it can be forced with a successful DC 18 Strength check.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 or more charges in this area causes one clone per charge to gain sentience, awaken, and demand to be set free. If all four are awakened, {@creature Thessalar|IMR} arrives to investigate.

entries.name: 24. Halls of Statues
entries: This series of long hallways are each lined with statues created by the temple's sculptors through the ages. Many depict Moloch, but other archdevils, demon lords, and former high priests of the temple are also represented. A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check identifies any statue's specific subject, including several statues of Demogorgon, Asmodeus, Dagon, Bel, Zariel, Mammon, and Semuanya.

entries.name: Sacred Statues
entries: Ten of the statues in this area are large enough to serve as {@creature Sacred Statue|MTF|sacred statues}. The {@creature eidolon|MTF} in area 25 can enter and animate those statues as needed (see {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7}).

The sacred statues can be attacked to destroy them, preventing the eidolon from animating them. When not occupied by the eidolon, each statue has AC 17, 50 hit points, resistance to piercing and slashing damage, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. A sacred statue is also vulnerable to the set of superior mason's tools found in {@area area 11|08a|x} of {@adventure chapter 3|IMR|3}. A character proficient with mason's tools can use the superior set to destroy a sacred statue with a successful DC 13 Dexterity check.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 or more charges in this area causes one sacred statue per charge to age and crumble to rubble, as long as the statue is not occupied by the eidolon.

The north end of this vaulted chamber is entirely filled by the temple's famed statue of Moloch. The impressive figure rises twenty-five feet high, nearly touching the ceiling. Its hands hold a massive burning brazier, illuminating the chamber with an eerie flickering glow. The brazier's fire reflects brightly within the facets of the statue's massive ruby eyes.

entries.name: Statue of Moloch
entries: The eyes of the statue are the largest rubies ever recovered from the underground lake, and were cut and faceted by the temple's first priests. With a successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check or a {@spell detect magic} spell, a character discerns that the gem eyes are a focal point for the magic of the temple, and are magically connected to the various control panels making use of the missing components from the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad}. A successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check made to examine the gems reveals that they are connected to the statue with silver wires similar to those seen in {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s labs.

The gems can be removed with a successful DC 20 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. However, doing so deactivates any control panel still utilizing components from the {@i Infernal Machine} in the temple (in areas 9, 14, 15, 16, and 22). This disrupts the experiments and frees the bound creatures in all those areas.

The {@creature eidolon|MTF} in this area (see below) can enter the statue to transform it into a {@creature sacred statue|MTF}. The statue can be attacked to destroy it, preventing the eidolon from animating it. When not occupied by the eidolon, the statue has AC 17, 50 hit points, resistance to piercing and slashing damage, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. The statue is also vulnerable to the set of superior mason's tools found in {@area area 11|08a|x} of {@adventure chapter 3|IMR|3}. A character proficient with mason's tools can use the superior set to destroy the statue with a successful DC 13 Dexterity check.
If the sacred statue is destroyed, the eidolon can enter one of the other appropriate statues in area 24.

entries.name: Alcove
entries: In the east wall, a narrow corridor leads to a tiny chapel room where the temple's first high priest communed with Moloch. After the priest's death, Moloch rewarded their faithful service by transforming him them into the {@creature eidolon|MTF} that still resides here.
If the characters desecrate any part of the temple, including tampering with or examining the statue's gemstone eyes, the eidolon enters the sacred statue of Moloch and attacks.

entries.name: Concealed Door
entries: In the southeast corner of this area, a door concealed behind a tapestry leads to the guardroom ({@area area 34|15d|x}). A fight between the characters and the eidolon (in or out of the sacred statue) is heard by the guards, who rush up to investigate.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Notwithstanding their value to {@creature Moghadam|IMR} and {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, the statue's gemstone eyes are worth 5,000 gp each.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area forces the eidolon to either enter or leave the sacred statue. Doing so causes the eidolon to attack if it is not already in combat with the characters.

entries.name: 26. Workshop
entries: The temple's sculptors labor in this workshop, which is filled with tables and benches covered in tools and raw materials for the crafting and repair of statuary.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The five human sculptors here (use the {@creature cultist} stat block) work feverishly to cover for the absence of the colleagues who left for the Tomb of Horrors. If the characters talk to them, the sculptors assume they were sent from the tomb as well, and ask about their missing colleagues. The sculptors share that {@creature Thessalar|IMR} has captured the thieves sent out by {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, including the gemsmith in {@area area 31|151|x}). They also know about the eidolon in area 25, and that this area of the temple is guarded by a two-headed giant called "the Demogorgon" (in {@area area 35|15f|x}).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In addition to ten rubies (worth 50 gp each) being worked into statues, this area contains two sets of {@item jeweler's tools|PHB} and {@item mason's tools|PHB}, as well as half a {@item manual of stone golems}. This is the torn matching half of the half manual held by the sculptors in {@area area 11|08a|x} of {@adventure chapter 3|IMR|3}. Even incomplete, it is worth 500 gp.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the sculptors to leave and return to their dormitory ({@area area 33|15a|x}).

entries.name: 27. Workshop and Storage
entries: This area holds a large kiln, which is constantly lit and used for the crafting of statues, homunculi, and other objects for the temple. Tools, chunks of stone, and lumps of clay wrapped in cloth are scattered about.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the homunculus in {@area area 15|110|x} to return here (its place of origin).

entries.name: 28. Private Chapel
entries: The temple's high priest resides in these small quarters, which contain a bed, personal effects, ceremonial robes, and religious instruments of office. A fireplace along the northeast wall is carved to resemble a smaller version of the famed statue of Moloch.

entries.name: Alcoves
entries: The larger alcove to the south of this area holds a pile of sacred stones for the construction of a powerful stone golem. This stone supposedly fell from Ogrémoch's body during the fight against Olhydra that carved out the first of the temple caverns. The smaller alcove holds the golem under construction. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} hopes to recover his sculptors, their superior mason's tools, and their half of the {@item manual of stone golems} to complete this golem and send it out against {@creature Moghadam|IMR}.

entries.name: High Priest
entries: Ard-Sagart (a lawful evil male human {@creature warlock of the fiend|VGM}) is here when the characters arrive, praying before the fireplace. With the loss of the sculptors in {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s service, he believes the temple has lost favor with Moloch. To remedy this, he has requested more lizardfolk to brave the underwater lake and collect gemstones as tribute. He is preparing to bless the next volunteers.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A secret door to the underground lake is hidden within the fireplace, and can be detected with a successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. The image of the brazier held by the statue of Moloch is worked into the fireplace hearth. Two types of offering can be placed in this graven brazier—either a character's sacrifice of blood (represented by a self-inflicted wound that deals 5 piercing or slashing damage) or a gemstone of any value. Either offering is consumed when given, whereupon the fireplace flames magically lower and the secret door in the back of the fireplace opens.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the high priest to leave for area 29 by way of the secret door, then prepare for a ceremony of blessing.

entries.name: 29. Secret Equipment Room
entries: Gear and equipment related to exploring the underground lake are stored in this private chapel to the temple's living demigod, the thessalkraken. Search and salvage gear are normally assigned to the lizardfolk charged with searching the subterranean lake for gems. Before entering the lake, the lizardfolk are blessed by the high priest in front of a smaller version of the statue of Moloch, modified to resemble the thessalkraken by having its arms changed into tentacles and its mouth filled with long needle-like teeth.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In addition to mundane gear, this area contains a {@item folding boat}, a {@item helm of underwater action|GoS} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}), and an incomplete {@item apparatus of Kwalish}. The missing levers of the apparatus can be found in {@area area 7|0e5|x}, and require a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check or a Dexterity check using thieves' tools or tinker's tools to reassemble.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes {@dice 1d4} {@creature Lizardfolk Render|GoS|lizardfolk renders} to arrive for the priest's blessing before departing down the stairs to the underground lake (area 30). They attack unless they can be convinced the characters are part of the blessing ceremony.

entries.name: 30. Hidden Stairs
entries: This winding set of stairs leads down to a natural cavern system below the temple. The main cavern is filled with a vast subterranean lake, fed by the stream at {@area area 2|0cd|x}. See "Underground Lake" at the end of this chapter for more information.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the thessalkraken to reveal itself as it breaks the surface of the water seeking food. Spending 2 charges also causes {@dice 1d4} {@creature Lizardfolk Render|GoS|lizardfolk renders} to arrive, ready to brave the waters in search of gems. The lizardfolk take the appearance of the characters as a sign of offering, and attempt to force them into the water as sacrifices for their demigod.

entries.name: 31. Gemsmith's Cell
entries: The oak door leading to this area is locked, but can be opened with a successful DC 14 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or forced open with a successful DC 14 Strength check. The chamber beyond holds the temple's most valued prisoner, {@creature Seodra|IMR} the gemsmith.

This room contains a cot, a footlocker, a basin, and a worktable covered in various tools. The table is presently occupied by a female genasi, her skin encrusted with patches of faceted crystals. The project she's working on is a silver skull with jeweled teeth.
Not bothering to look at you, the genasi says, "Your interruptions are not helping. For the last time, tell {@creature Thessalar|IMR} I need more time to finish!"

entries.name: The Gemsmith
entries: {@creature Seodra|IMR} is an earth genasi from the Quasi-elemental Plane of Mineral. Sent by {@creature Moghadam|IMR} to assist the thieves charged with stealing the gemstone eyes from the statue of Moloch in {@area area 25|13a|x}, she was captured and put to work.

If the characters talk of rescuing her, {@creature Seodra|IMR} refuses to leave unless they also promise to help her steal the statue's eyes. She takes her tools and the silver skull if the characters convince her to come with them. {@creature Seodra|IMR} uses the {@creature noble} stat block with the following changes:

items: She has AC 19 (natural armor).
She speaks Common and Primordial.
She can move across {@quickref difficult terrain||3} made of stone without expending extra movement.
She has the following trait: {@b {@i Treasure Sense}.} {@creature Seodra|IMR} can pinpoint, by scent, the location of precious metals and stones, such as coins and gems, within 60 feet of her.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The worktable contains the workings for the jeweled skull of a demilich: a solid silver skull (worth 2,000 gp) into which three diamonds (1,000 gp each) have been cut and set as teeth. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} plans to use the skull for his own ascension to lichdom, either as his lich's phylactery or as the skull of a demilich.
{@creature Seodra|IMR} possesses a set of superior {@item jeweler's tools|PHB}. These tools grant advantage when used to make an appropriate crafting check, and are worth 500 gp.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area taps into the ritual magic {@creature Seodra|IMR} is using to craft the demilich's skull, causing a random character to age by one year. This effect can be reversed by casting a {@spell remove curse} spell using a 6th-level spell slot.

entries.name: 32. Guardroom
entries: Four {@creature Lizardfolk Render|GoS|lizardfolk renders} are stationed here, assigned to watch over the gemsmith in area 31.

entries.name: Corridor
entries: The small corridor leading east across from the guardroom dead-ends at a point with several natural fissures in the floor (leading to the underground lake below), and is used as a privy.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the lizardfolk to head into the temple complex to search for {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, believing the thieves have just arrived. You determine where the guards might be encountered as a result.

entries.name: 33. Sculptors' Dormitory
entries: This cramped dormitory holds bunks and simple furnishings for the fifteen sculptors originally living in the temple. Ten of those sculptors left the temple to work at the Tomb of Horrors, with only five remaining at work in {@area area 26|141|x}.

entries.name: Belongings
entries: A successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check made to search this area uncovers a {@item figurine of wondrous power} hidden by one of the sculptors (choose any rare figurine). The figurine is wrapped in a crumpled invitation sent from {@creature Moghadam|IMR} for employment at the Tomb of Horrors, promising exorbitant wages and offering a map showing the route to the temple.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the sculptors to leave their work in {@area area 26|141|x} and return here to rest.

entries.name: 34. Guardroom
entries: Four {@creature Lizardfolk Shaman||lizardfolk shamans} are stationed here as temple guards. If they hear any sign of trouble along the corridor from {@area area 25|13a|x}, they rush through the concealed doors to help defend the eidolon and the sacred statue there.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the lizardfolk to head into the temple complex to search for {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s thieves, believing the thieves have just arrived. You determine where the guards might be encountered as a result.

entries.name: 35. Office of the Demogorgon
entries: This area houses an ettin, originally brought here for {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s experiments. The giant is kept both for his blood supply, which {@creature Thessalar|IMR} uses in the crafting of new two-headed creatures, and as a guard for the treasure vault ({@area area 38|16b|x}).
As the characters approach the entrance to this area, read:
A deep voice cries out through the open doorway ahead, quickly responded to by a second voice.
"So! You come to honor Emmanuel, right head of the Demogorgon!"
"No! You honor Hebediah, left head of Demogorgon!"
When the characters can see into this area, read:

This filthy chamber is occupied by an ettin who is the source of the bellowing. The right head of the creature sports a stylish beard, while the left head has a large, curving mustache. Silver wires extend from a large pouch hanging around the giant's two necks, connecting directly into his chest. A pig snoozes on the floor at the ettin's feet.
"Stand still!" one head roars. "My steward Slippy will present you for a formal audience."
"No! My steward Sticky will present you!"
Both heads then ignore you as they begin bellowing over one another for Slippy and Sticky to attend them.

entries.name: The Demogorgon
entries: {@creature "The Demogorgon"|IMR|This ettin} is thoroughly deranged, with {@creature Thessalar|IMR} cruelly humoring the creature's condition in his "honored" treatment. See {@adventure appendix B|IMR|7} for {@creature "The Demogorgon"|IMR|the ettin's} stat block. At one time, he was told that he was a statue of Demogorgon brought to life by {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s experiments. He has since come to believe that he is now the actual Demogorgon, with his two heads addressing one another as Aameul and Hathradiah—mispronounced as Emmanuel and Hebediah, respectively. A successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check allows a character to recall the real names of Demogorgon's heads.

Much like the true Demogorgon, the ettin's two heads constantly clash and refuse to speak directly with one another, instead relaying messages through their assigned stewards (housed in areas 36 and 37).

If the ettin is defeated, examining the pouches around his necks reveals a collection of eyeballs and still-beating dragon hearts. The silver wires connect those living tissues to the ettin's own hearts, providing the creature's unique features. This setup is made permanently inoperable if the ettin is slain.
Anyone attempting to disrupt the wires must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) force damage. The wires are self-repairing, and cannot be severed or destroyed.

entries.name: Alcoves
entries: Various alcoves and side passages around this area hold a foul-smelling clutter of chickens, pigs, and goats kept behind wicker barricades, raised as food for the ettin. They are tended by the boggle who is steward to both the ettin's heads (see areas 36 and 37).

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the chickens to lay more eggs, to the delight of the ettin. Both his heads call out for their steward to gather the eggs at once.

entries.name: 36. Office of Hebediah's Steward
entries: This office apartment houses the steward assigned to the ettin's left head (Hebediah). The room is meagerly furnished with a cot and a single chair, and connects to area 37 via a short hall hidden behind a poorly hung curtain. The tunnel is easily discovered with a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: "Slippy"
entries: If not already met when summoned to area 35, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the steward to the ettin is found in this area. If not in this area, the boggle is in area 37.

This {@creature boggle|VGM} was one of two caught trying to use their Dimensional Rift traits to reach into the temple's treasure vault ({@area area 38|16b|x}). As punishment, they were assigned to provide care and grooming to the ettin's left and right heads, as well as relaying messages on the giant's behalf. When the ettin wants to talk to himself, one head gives the message to his steward, who runs off to deliver it to the other steward, who runs back to deliver it to the other head, and back down the line.

The two stewards are identical except for an epaulet worn on the left or right shoulder of their livery, but they have of late never been seen together. This is because only one boggle remains, the companion boggle having been disposed of in {@area area 7|0e5|x}. Both stewards are thus now the same creature, who works hard to make sure this is never discovered. The boggle intuits (correctly) that if the ettin were to uncover this secret, he would rip the boggle in half as a furious means of getting the proper number of stewards once more.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the steward to run back if they are elsewhere, or rush off to perform some task or deliver a muddled message to the ettin. In the course of doing so, they confuse matters such that their true nature as steward to both heads is accidentally revealed, incurring the ettin's wrath.

If 1 more charge is subsequently spent, things instead rewind and the ettin forgets all. The steward realizes they have been saved and is eternally grateful to the characters, helping them in any way possible.

entries.name: 37. Office of Emmanuel's Steward
entries: This office apartment houses the steward assigned to the ettin's right head (Emmanuel). It is meagerly furnished with a cot and a small table, and connects to area 36 via a panel hidden behind a poorly hung curtain. The tunnel is easily discovered with a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: "Sticky"
entries: If not already met when summoned to {@area area 35|15f|x}, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the steward to the ettin is found in this area. If not in this area, the {@creature boggle|VGM} is in area 36. See area 36 for details on the identity of Sticky and Slippy.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend charges in this area has the same effect as in area 36.

entries.name: 38. Treasure Vault
entries: The wealth the temple has collected over centuries is stored in this hidden vault. Much of this wealth consists of gemstones gathered from the underground lake beyond areas 30 and 39.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: The secret door leading into this area can be detected with a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, but is locked. Without the key (found in {@area area 2|0cd|x} or {@area area 20|127|x}), the lock requires a successful DC 18 Dexterity check using thieves' tools to open, or it can be forced open with a successful DC 22 Strength check.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Uncut rubies and other gems are piled and sorted here according to size—two hundred tiny stones (worth 10 gp each), one hundred small stones (25 gp each), twenty medium stones (100 gp each), and five large stones (200 gp each).
A small cask holds cut and polished rubies—fifty small gems (worth 100 gp each), ten medium gems (150 gp each), and five large gems (250 gp each).

In addition, five magic gems and stones are stored in individual coffers scattered about the room—an {@item Elemental Gem, Yellow Diamond||elemental gem (earth)}, an {@item Ioun stone of vitality|IMR} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}), and three {@item Spell Gem|OotA|spell gems} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}). Two of the spell gems are {@item Spell Gem (Lapis lazuli)|OotA|lapis lazuli} holding {@spell identify} and {@spell unseen servant}. The third is a {@item Spell Gem (Quartz)|OotA|quartz} holding {@spell locate object}.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area either causes {@dice 1d4} of the largest uncut rubies to become cut and polished, doubling their value (a {@chance 50} chance), or causes the same number of the largest cut rubies to degrade back to raw stones, halving their value.

entries.name: 39. Stairs to Underground Lake
entries: These twisting, turning stairs lead down to the underground lake that opens up beneath the temple complex.

entries.name: Underground Lake
entries: The full details of the natural cavern system that opens up below the temple are left for you to design if desired. The main cavern, reached by the stairs at {@area area 30|14f|x} or 39, is filled by a subterranean lake fed by the stream at {@area area 2|0cd|x}.
When the characters descend the stairs at {@area area 30|14f|x} or area 39, read:

The stairs end abruptly, opening up to a vast natural cavern deep beneath the temple. A pebbly beach extends toward the dark waters of a subterranean lake that fills the cavern, a cold wind blowing across it.
If the characters have light sources with them, anyone peering into the water notes a dull red gleam where a raw ruby sits at the bottom of the lake near the shore.
Any creature setting foot on the beach or entering the water must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check or rouse the dread creature lurking within the lake.

entries.name: Creature
entries: One of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s monstrous creations, the {@creature thessalkraken|IMR} proved too dangerous to safely handle and was exiled to these caverns years ago. It has since grown too large to return to the temple, and now serves as a kind of living demigod to the cultists and lizardfolk serving {@creature Thessalar|IMR}, who refer to it as the "Child of Moloch."

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Lizardfolk in service to {@creature Thessalar|IMR} are sent here to brave the waters and attempt to recover more gemstones from the bottom of the lake. When the characters arrive here, the bottom of the lake is littered with {@dice 1d10} rubies. Roll a {@dice d10} to determine the value of each ruby found—
If all the rubies are claimed, it takes 24 hours for more rubies to appear in the lake.
The bottom of the lake is also covered with the cracked bones of the many creatures sacrificed to the thessalkraken, or who ran afoul of it while diving for gems.

entries.name: Manipulating Time
entries: Having a mechanical guide spend 1 charge in this area causes the thessalkraken to break the surface of the water seeking food, thus revealing itself. Spending 2 charges also causes {@dice 1d4} {@creature Lizardfolk Render|GoS|lizardfolk renders} to arrive, ready to brave the waters in search of gemstones. The lizardfolk take the appearance of the characters as a sign of offering, and attempt to force them into the water as sacrifices for their demigod.

data.name: Chapter 5: Final Showdown
entries: After visiting the Tomb of Horrors or the Temple of Moloch (or both), the characters should have recovered some of the missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Whenever they return to their original time, Lynx and {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} both make a play for the components, desiring to use them to complete and control the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad}.

entries.name: Special Delivery
entries: Whichever agent the characters are working for, their mechanical guide is programmed to teleport them back to the agent's manor. If the characters somehow obtained both mechanical guides, they can decide which agent they want to initially return to. (Even if the characters have done secret deals with both agents, they should choose one to be their initial contact upon their return to their original time.)

If the characters somehow manage to return to their original time at any other location, a courier arrives at that location shortly thereafter, delivering an urgent invitation to come to the manor to discuss the results of their expedition. If the characters have the intent of avoiding the agent, the agent comes to find them in short order, and arranges for their mechanical guide to teleport everyone back to the manor.

entries.name: Formal Review
entries: When the characters meet with their chosen agent, Lynx or {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} asks to inspect any missing components they've collected. The agent agrees to pay the characters as arranged, but only after their servants test that the components are in working order. The characters are then led to the agent's workshop. As they go, the agent talks about deducting expenses for any resources used, damage to the mechanical guide, and so forth—in general, becoming increasingly insidious.

entries.name: Completing the Machine
entries: When the characters first see the workshop, they become aware of the scope of what the agent is hoping to achieve.

The entire workshop is filled with a massive magical-mechanical device, worked on by a half-dozen servants. With no visible means to move it, the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad} must presumably have the power to teleport itself from place to place. It appears ancient, the style of its crafting unlike anything you've ever seen before. It features some sixty levers, forty dials, and twenty massive switches, as well as a booth large enough to hold four humans—but whether those humans would be the machine's operators or the targets for its magic is unknown.

When the components the characters collected are presented, the agent's assistants (six {@creature Cultist||cultists} in official-looking white lab coats) work quickly to install those components into the {@i Infernal Machine}. The mechanical guide that's accompanied the characters attaches itself to the machine, allowing it to serve as a command unit.
Another six {@creature Cultist||cultists} then appear with the agent's secret prisoner to finalize the programming.

A door on the far side of the workshop opens, and six more assistants stride forth with a weary-looking prisoner in tow. A human male with a haughty bearing, and wearing tattered, once-regal clothes, the figure gazes up at the great machine with a sense of recognition and longing.
Your host laughs, gesturing toward the figure with a flourish. "Adventurers! May I present Lum the Mad!"

entries.name: Lum the Mad
entries: In response to any reaction or questions, the agent proudly explains how the partially functioning {@i Infernal Machine} was used to find and capture Lum the Mad, so that he could assist in restoring the machine to its primal state.

Lum uses the {@creature warlord|VGM} stat block, but is unarmed and has no attacks while under guard. He possesses sufficient knowledge to program the {@i Infernal Machine}, allowing it to fully function according to its description now that the missing components have been restored. In his state of low-grade madness, Lum has no reason to not follow the agent's orders and help bring the machine online. However, he is also able to deactivate the machine, or even cause it to self-destruct—if the characters can convince him to do so with appropriate roleplaying or Charisma checks of your determination.

entries.name: Raid Against the Machine
entries: Immediately after the missing components are installed and Lum is presented, the other agent launches a surprise raid against the first agent's manor. Read the following, adding details as appropriate depending on whether Lynx or {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} is the one coming for the {@i Infernal Machine}, and whether or not the characters have met the other agent:
A sudden shattering crash is heard as the wall of the workshop collapses to rubble! A fighting force advances through a cloud of dust, led by a most unusual-looking figure.
The other agent arrives with a full complement of a dozen servants (use the {@creature cultist} stat block).

During the raid, both agents attempt to attune to the {@i Infernal Machine}. You can decide which one is successful or allow chance to decide (see "Complications" below), taking into account the actions of the characters if they support one agent or the other.

During the fight, both agents shout out accusations that reveal the other's true natures. Those natures are then confirmed by the agents themselves. Any injury dealt to {@creature Lynx Creatlach|IMR} shows the unnatural construction of her undead flesh and the rune-scribed skeleton beneath it. Any injury dealt to {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} causes him to shout out in rage, swearing vengeance "in the name of my unholy patron, Bel!"

If either agent gains control of the {@i Infernal Machine}, they immediately use it to attempt to defeat their rival. (The machine has all its normal functions except its {@spell wish} ability, which will require additional programming.) If confronted by the characters, the agent turns the {@i Infernal Machine} against them. If the characters leave the agent in control of the machine, the agent departs with it to the Nine Hells when their rival has been dealt with.

entries.name: Complications
entries: During the raid, any number of complications might arise. As desired, you can roll on the Machine Fight Complications table (see the next page) at the end of each round of combat, rerolling or ignoring results that have already occurred.

entries.name: Failure Is an Option
entries: If the characters failed to recover a significant number of components from either site in the past—and assuming you don't want to send them back—you can work that into this final showdown. Whichever agent the characters return to is disappointed in their progress, but comes up with an alternative plan. Knowing that the other agent might also have sent their own operatives back to collect the missing components, the characters' agent invites them to help break into the rival agent's workshop to steal those components from the rival's version of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Reverse the general setup of this section to have the characters on the side that breaks into the workshop. There, they see the rival agent holding Lum the Mad, and in the process of completing the {@i Infernal Machine}.

entries.caption: Machine Fight Complications
rows: Lynx attunes to the {@i Infernal Machine} and begins to use its powers.
{@dice 2d8} secret operatives of the city guard (use the {@creature spy} stat block) have been watching one or both agents, and show up to attempt to stop the fight.
Lum is threatened by cultists of one agent or the other. If aided, he agrees to work with the characters in whatever fashion they desire.
The {@i Infernal Machine} comes to life, summoning a CR 5 monster (your choice) that attacks the creatures closest to it.
The {@i Infernal Machine} comes to life, summoning a CR 10 monster (your choice) that attacks the creatures closest to it.
A spellcaster fighting for Lynx casts a {@spell lightning bolt} that streaks across the battlefield to strike targets as you determine.
A spellcaster fighting for {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} casts a {@spell fireball} that explodes at a location of your determination.
Lynx slays {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR}. She cuts off his bear paw, promising to turn it into her personal backscratcher.
{@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} slays Lynx. He tears her flesh golem suit away to reveal the skeleton within, which he then shatters. Lynx's skull might still remain animated and conversational.
Both Lynx and {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} manage to slay one another simultaneously.
Both Lynx and {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} decide that events have grown too heated and escape into the city. High bounties are set for their capture.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: Depending on the hook you used and how this adventure fits into your overall campaign, a number of things can happen at the end of {@i Infernal Machine Rebuild}.

entries.name: Nine Hells or Bust
entries: If either agent is successful in taking the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad} to the Nine Hells, it changes the balance of power in Avernus. Either Zariel is able to solidify her rule of that level, or Bel is able to reclaim the level using the machine's power. What happens as a result is entirely up to you, and might come into play if you are running {@adventure Baldur's Gate: Descent into Avernus|BGDIA} as part of your campaign.

entries.name: Finders Keepers
entries: If the characters plan on keeping the missing {@i Infernal Machine} components for themselves, for delivery to another patron (such as Kwalish), or simply to keep them out of the hands of the agents, both Lynx and {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} launch separate attacks to recover them. These attacks can either be spaced out to avoid overwhelming the characters, or you can have both agents attack at the same time and largely concentrate on each other.

entries.name: Our Infernal Machine
entries: If one or both of Lynx and {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} are defeated, the characters might end up in possession of the {@i Infernal Machine}. If you opt to keep this powerful artifact in your campaign, see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8} for its statistics. Otherwise, you can decide that the machine has been fatally programmed to disperse its components to all-new locations—but only after the characters have had a bit of time to experiment with it.

Of course, if the characters take possession of the machine for any length of time, any surviving agents seek revenge against them. Likewise, so will the agents' patron archdevils, Zariel and Bel, who might send forces of cultists to finish the characters off.

entries.name: Mechanical Guides
entries: The mechanical guides are programmed to serve their agent masters—and to self-destruct in the event that anyone else attempts to take control of them. Still, exposure to the power of the components of the {@i Infernal Machine} might change a guide's programming, allowing the characters to befriend and permanently claim it as a companion or ally. If this happens, a guide's time traveling ability can be curtailed as you desire.

entries.name: The Joys of Time Travel
entries: Because this adventure traverses both time and space, you might decide that actions carried out by the characters in the past of chapters 3 and 4 create changes in the present of the campaign world when they return. For example, the construction of the Tomb of Horrors might be disrupted, in which case it holds less prominence in later times. If {@creature Thessalar|IMR} regains his missing sculptors, he might complete his stone golem and send it out to destroy {@creature Moghadam|IMR} and demolish the tomb while it's under construction. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} might also create more monsters than he is already known for, which can spread throughout the world.
Feel free to keep track of what events and choices in the past might have future implications—and have fun presenting the fallout of those events to your players!

data.name: Appendix A: Further Options
entries: {@i Infernal Machine Rebuild} hopefully provides plenty of options for you to run the adventure the way that works best for your campaign. But if you'd like to customize this adventure even further, consider any of the following possibilities.

entries.name: Chapter 1: The Unicorn and the Hags
entries: The conflict between the hags and the unicorn {@creature Banrion|IMR} can be complicated or augmented in a number of ways.

entries.name: Clandestine Hags
entries: If having three dryads working together is too immediate a tipoff that these might be hags forming a coven, you can add a fourth illusory mother to the mix to help allay suspicion. Created from a few logs and branches, Mother Hedgehog sits quietly in the corner of the cottage. If the characters attempt to speak with her, the programmed illusion is able to mumble a few incoherent words. A successful DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check detects this illusion.

The hags' cottage is built from three trees entwined together. These trees might contain the three true dryads whose appearances the hags have stolen for their own use, and who have been enslaved by the hags to help with their corrupt gardening. If the characters treat with {@creature Banrion|IMR}, the unicorn asks them to help free the dryads to set the woods back to order.

Instead of the hags being disguised as goodly dryads, you might instead choose to reverse the scenario. The Three Mothers might really be dryads in need of help, with {@creature Banrion|IMR} the unicorn an evil creature that must be defeated to save the woods. The unicorn might even be using its dark magic to cause the dryads to appear as hags.

entries.name: Unicorn Showdown
entries: If the characters initially make an aggressive approach toward {@creature Banrion|IMR} (whether because the hags have fooled them or because the unicorn is evil), you can make the fight tougher by having the unicorn appear while the characters are attempting to cross the clock tower bridge. While fighting on the bridge, {@creature Banrion|IMR} looks to knock characters off the tower into the chasm below, or even to try to collapse the tower under the characters while she teleports away.
If the unicorn later makes peace with the characters, she teleports down into the chasm (if still able to) and heals them.

entries.name: Chapter 2: An Invitation Extended
entries: Meeting with the infernal agents has the potential for a number of interesting story options.

entries.name: Updated Guides
entries: As written, the mechanical guides can safely teleport the characters to and from the specific adventure locations. If it fits with your campaign, you might opt to allow teleportation to other locations in time and space with a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check. A failed check causes the characters to be misdirected physically or temporally, as you determine. If the characters claim any missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}, those components can be added to the mechanical guide, providing a +2 bonus to this check per component.

You might decide that neither agent would ever allow the components they already possess to leave their sight, or that the characters are the first ones to have come across any missing components. If so, Lynx's guide is powered by a dangerous combination of living {@spell teleport} and {@spell time stop} spells, and might malfunction as you see fit. {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR}'s guide is a captured quarut (an inevitable that seeks to uphold the laws of space and time), and which is forced to use its powers as Ursas demands. Though the quarut is programmed to prevent it from revealing its plight outright, it might provide clues during the adventure that all is not as it seems.

entries.name: Healthy Competition
entries: When the characters make their choice of which agent they want to work with, whatever agent they turn down immediately arranges to send out their own competing expedition. (If the characters agree to work for both agents, both agents might still send out second redundant expeditions as insurance.)

These expeditions are composed of five {@creature cultist} servants, led either by the {@creature enhanced medusa|IMR} for Lynx, or the brains in iron for {@creature Sir Ursas|IMR} (see below for more information on both). Each expedition also has its own mechanical guide. You might use the members of the rival expedition to chase after the characters, or they might have already arrived at one of the locations and be set up for the characters to stumble upon. The members of the alternative expedition might set obstacles along the way, possibly inspiring the characters to do the same. Using the power of a mechanical guide might allow for the creation of particularly devious traps that can be set across space and time. And the members of the alternative expedition certainly look to sabotage or destroy the characters' mechanical guide in order to strand them.

These competitors might succeed in securing some of the missing components, whether they steal them out from under the characters or take them directly in combat. Any stolen components will be delivered to their respective agents before the characters return from the past.

entries.name: Enhanced Medusa
entries: Like the enhanced sphinx from {@adventure Lost Laboratory of Kwalish|LLK}, this creature has been augmented with various technologies from the Barrier Peaks. Specifically, its eyes have been replaced with mechanical frames into which it slots different lenses. This is the same magical technology that was used to create another artifact, {@i Daoud's Wondrous Lanthorn}. The medusa is nicknamed "Daoud's Living Lanthorn" as a result.
The {@creature enhanced medusa|IMR} uses the {@creature medusa} stat block with the following changes:

items: It has {@sense truesight} out to a range of 60 feet.
It can cast the {@spell light} cantrip at will.
Its Petrifying Gaze trait turns creatures into metal, wood, or porcelain (the medusa's choice) rather than stone.

entries: If this adventure is played as a sequel to {@adventure Lost Laboratory of Kwalish|LLK}, the {@creature enhanced medusa|IMR} might seek revenge for what befell its ancestor {@creature Gloine Nathair-Nathair|LLK}, or could be appeased with information regarding that medusa's whereabouts.

entries.name: Who's Who
entries: While little is known of Daoud, his lanthorn was part of the treasure to be recovered in the AD&D adventure module {@i Lost Caverns of Tsojcanth}. Light cast through the different faces of the lanthorn created different magical effects, which the lanthorn fueled with crushed gemstones.

entries.name: Brains in Iron (The Council)
entries: This creature originated from old designs of Kwalish, and takes the form of multiple brains that have been magically preserved and which collectively operate a new mechanical body. The brains share insights and knowledge with one another, and have typically been taken from creatures that desired to prolong their consciousness—or that were tasked with controlling a construct for all time as punishment.
A {@creature brain in iron|IMR} uses the {@creature brain in a jar|LLK} stat block with the following changes:

items: It is lawful neutral.
It has the construct type.
Its size is Large.
It has Armor Class 15 (natural armor).
It has a speed of 20 feet.

entries: If this adventure is played as a sequel to {@adventure Lost Laboratory of Kwalish|LLK}, this creature began as the brains in jars encountered in the Barrier Peaks. After constructing a new collective body from spare parts, the brains escaped (and now seek revenge against the characters if they did not aid the brains sufficiently during that adventure). The brains' collective goal in seeking the missing components is to be able to transfer themselves into the ultimate mechanical body—the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad}.

entries.name: Chapter 3: Construction of Horrors
entries: You can expand the characters' exploration of the Tomb of Horrors construction site in a number of ways.

entries.name: Hanging with Moghadam
entries: Even villains have their hobbies—and for {@creature Moghadam|IMR}, that hobby is death traps. Any character who discusses traps with {@creature Moghadam|IMR} can impart to him a new deadly design—either using suitable roleplaying and player ingenuity, or a successful DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. Doing so gains {@creature Moghadam|IMR}'s favor and advantage on further ability checks made to negotiate with the artificer, as you determine.

entries.name: Muralist Mutiny
entries: As written, the sculptors in the Tomb of Horrors are eager to escape but the muralists are loyal to {@creature Moghadam|IMR}. However, you might decide that the muralists have their own reasons to flee servitude, and have secured a set of {@item claws of the umber hulk|PotA} (see {@adventure appendix C|IMR|8}) to do so. They might also look for the characters' help to escape, using the claws to dig a secret tunnel beneath their chambers in {@area area 9|07d|x}—and potentially intersecting with the umber hulks' excavations.

entries.name: Rock and Ruin
entries: As an added element of danger and dilemma during the ceremony in the chapel ({@area area 14|093|x}), each time a character succeeds on a saving throw to resist the ceremony's power, one of the worshipers in the pews is overcome and transforms into black rock.

If the black rocks from the chapel are brought to the sculptors, you might decide that they can help restore those victims to life using their superior mason's tools. Alternatively, the sculptors might want to incorporate these magic rocks into an even more impressive golem, helping to ensure their escape. Likewise, if taken to the Temple of Moloch, these rocks might be highly prized for the crafting of statues and homunculi.

entries.name: Go to Hell
entries: The fiery rift of area 16 allows {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} to return to the Abyss. But depending on the setup of your campaign (and particularly if you are playing through {@adventure Baldur's Gate: Descent into Avernus|BGDIA}), you might instead have this rift lead to the Nine Hells. There, {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} joins the demonic horde taking part in the Blood War.
If the characters later travel through Avernus, they might encounter {@creature Tarnhem|IMR} there—with his reaction to them depending on their interactions at the tomb.

entries.name: Chapter 4: Temple of Moloch
entries: The level of chaos and creative power on display in the Temple of Moloch lends itself to a number of play options.

entries.name: Trade Talk
entries: {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s fixation on monster design provides an opportunity for bonding with any character with insight into that topic—or who can fake it well enough, either using suitable roleplaying and player ingenuity, or a successful DC 16 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. Suggesting a new design for a magical creature (ideally one combining the aspects of two or more existing creatures in some particularly deadly way) can grant advantage on checks made to interact with the artificer.

entries.name: Tressym Patrol
entries: Considering the variety of laboratory creatures residing in the temple, its hallways might also be populated by roving packs of wild, escaped {@creature tressym|BGDIA}. These flying cats follow and spy on the characters, but might help lead them to various locations (such as the secret door outside {@area area 38|16b|x}) if treated well. The tressym despise {@creature Barbatos|IMR}'s {@creature hell hound} ({@area areas 12|102|x} and {@area 13|106|x}), and actively aid any effort to destroy it.

entries.name: Mixing up the Thieves
entries: If the characters pass through the village mentioned in the "{@area Temple Approach|0c1|x}" section, they might discover that one of the villagers is one of Mack Francache's thieves, left behind to keep an eye on activities outside the temple. When the characters arrive, this thief presents themself as a seemingly reluctant guide willing to join the characters on the incursion into the temple. While there, they secretly try to direct the characters toward rescuing the imprisoned thieves.

Mack Francache the wererat prisoner ({@area area 9|0eb|x}) might instead be a lycanthrope of some kind never seen before: a weremouse, a weremoose, or even a wereooze. {@creature Thessalar|IMR} is extremely interested in studying this new lycanthropy. Alternatively, Mack might have been a normal human when he came to the temple, only to have {@creature Thessalar|IMR} impose this strange lycanthropy upon him.

entries.name: Statuesque
entries: You might introduce different options for interacting with the statues in {@area area 24|136|x}, especially if combat breaks out there. For example, if the eidolon inhabits a statue of Zariel or Bel, the characters might gain advantage on attack rolls against that statue if they serve the archdevil's agent (or disadvantage on attack rolls against the statue of the competing agent's patron). Out of combat, if the characters are allied with {@creature Moghadam|IMR} and remove a hand and an eye from any statue, Vecna rewards them with some boon (advantage on attack rolls during the first round of their next fight, having a consumable magic item appear in the statue's remaining hand, and so forth).

entries.name: Secret Chicken
entries: One of the chickens in {@area area 35|15f|x} might be one of {@creature Thessalar|IMR}'s experiments, such that it occasionally lays silver eggs (worth 10 gp) or even golden eggs (worth 20 gp). In this scenario, both boggles originally came to the temple to steal this chicken. Or this might just be a tale the remaining boggle tells, planting false eggs with the chickens in order to better negotiate with the characters.

entries.name: Chapter 5: Final Showdown
entries: The presence of a legendary artifact in the final chapter of the adventure opens up lots of possibilities.

entries.name: An Infernal War Machine
entries: For deeper integration with {@adventure Baldur's Gate: Descent into Avernus|BGDIA}, an alternative climax could have the characters' chosen agent complete their version of the {@i Infernal Machine}—which is then converted into an infernal war machine. Such a process might involve drawing on other elements of the adventure's locations (the Tomb of Horrors' still-to-be-built stone juggernaut, the skeleton of the thessalkraken, and so forth) for use in the war machine's chassis.

The characters are then asked to drive the war machine into Avernus, to confront the minions of the archdevil opposed by their agent and thwart that archdevil's plans. Alternatively, the {@i Infernal War Machine} might be teleported to the Nine Hells, where the characters later encounter it during the course of {@adventure Baldur's Gate: Descent into Avernus|BGDIA} and are required to stop it.

entries.name: A Mighty Servant
entries: When the characters deliver the missing components to their chosen agent and the other agent launches a raid, that raid is led by a second artifact that the agent has been constructing—the {@i Mighty Servant of Leuk-O}. Alternatively, if Kwalish is involved, he might build or upgrade a suit of {@i powered armor} (from {@adventure Lost Laboratory of Kwalish|LLK}) to become the {@i Mighty Servant of Leuk-O}. The characters can then use that artifact (with features determined by you) to counter the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad}.

entries.name: Additional Locations
entries: You can turn this adventure into an entire campaign by adding additional locations containing more missing components of the {@i Infernal Machine}. Just as the Tomb of Horrors was repurposed here, you might similarly repurpose other adventures from D&D history or your previous campaigns, manipulating their time lines to create alternative scenarios.

So many of the iconic locations in D&D would make great additions to this adventure, from the tower of Sorcere in Menzoberranzan, to one of the elemental nodes in {@adventure Princes of the Apocalypse|PotA}, to the level of Dweomercore in {@adventure Dungeon of the Mad Mage|WDMM}, to Skyreach Castle in {@adventure Hoard of the Dragon Queen|HotDQ}. A few specific examples are presented here.

entries.name: Tomb of Annihilation
entries: Missing components could be hidden in any number of locations in the jungles of Chult, including the Lost City of Omu, or even integrated into the Tomb of the Nine Gods. For example, to recover a component located at the City of Omu's amphitheater, the characters might need to overcome the King of Feathers at some point in the past (making it a younger, weaker tyrannosaurus rex) or the future (where it has become a deadly dinosaur zombie).

entries.name: Glacial Rift of the Frost Giant Jarl
entries: Missing components could be hidden throughout many areas of this adventure from Tales from the Yawning Portal. In the caverns of area 5, components could be buried within the ice in a way that requires the characters to access them in the past—and allowing the creatures trapped in the ice to be brought back to life. In the visitors' cave of area 26, components might have been brought as special gifts by past dignitaries unaware of their true nature. And in the snow-covered dome of area 28, they might be guarded as treasure by the {@creature remorhaz}.

entries.name: White Plume Mountain
entries: The characters might need to travel back to a time when Keraptis first constructed his legendary dungeon (featured in {@adventure Tales from the Yawning Portal|TftYP-WPM}), and used components from the {@i Infernal Machine of Lum the Mad} to magically secure {@item Wave}, {@item Whelm}, and {@item Blackrazor} in place. Alternatively, he might trade missing components in his possession for the three famed weapons, which are still hidden elsewhere in the world, or for some of the monstrous creatures that will eventually guard the dungeon.
